trans-unit.source: Flask and Azure Table Storage on Azure with Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Flask and Azure Table Storage on Azure with Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Python Tools for Visual Studio to create a Flask web app that stores data in Azure Table Storage and deploy it to Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Python Tools for Visual Studio to create a Flask web app that stores data in Azure Table Storage and deploy it to Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Flask and Azure Table Storage on Azure with Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Flask and Azure Table Storage on Azure with Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll use [Python Tools for Visual Studio] to create a simple polls web app using one of the PTVS sample templates.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll use [Python Tools for Visual Studio] to create a simple polls web app using one of the PTVS sample templates.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is also available as a [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qUtZWtPwbTk).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is also available as a [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qUtZWtPwbTk).

trans-unit.source: The polls web app defines an abstraction for its repository, so you can easily switch between different types of repositories (In-Memory, Azure Table Storage, MongoDB).
trans-unit.target: The polls web app defines an abstraction for its repository, so you can easily switch between different types of repositories (In-Memory, Azure Table Storage, MongoDB).

trans-unit.source: We'll learn how to create an Azure Storage account, how to configure the web app to use Azure Table Storage, and how to publish the web app to [Azure App Service Web Apps](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714).
trans-unit.target: We'll learn how to create an Azure Storage account, how to configure the web app to use Azure Table Storage, and how to publish the web app to [Azure App Service Web Apps](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714).

trans-unit.source: See the [Python Developer Center] for more articles that cover development of Azure App Service Web Apps with PTVS using Bottle, Flask and Django web frameworks, with MongoDB, Azure Table Storage, MySQL and SQL Database services.
trans-unit.target: See the [Python Developer Center] for more articles that cover development of Azure App Service Web Apps with PTVS using Bottle, Flask and Django web frameworks, with MongoDB, Azure Table Storage, MySQL and SQL Database services.

trans-unit.source: While this article focuses on App Service, the steps are similar when developing [Azure Cloud Services].
trans-unit.target: While this article focuses on App Service, the steps are similar when developing [Azure Cloud Services].

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 or 2015
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 or 2015

trans-unit.source: Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio Samples VSIX
trans-unit.target: Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio Samples VSIX

trans-unit.source: [Azure SDK Tools for VS 2013] or [Azure SDK Tools for VS 2015]
trans-unit.target: [Azure SDK Tools for VS 2013] or [Azure SDK Tools for VS 2015]

trans-unit.source: [Python 2.7 32-bit] or [Python 3.4 32-bit]
trans-unit.target: [Python 2.7 32-bit] or [Python 3.4 32-bit]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Create the Project
trans-unit.target: Create the Project

trans-unit.source: In this section, we'll create a Visual Studio project using a sample template.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we'll create a Visual Studio project using a sample template.

trans-unit.source: We'll create a virtual environment and install required packages.
trans-unit.target: We'll create a virtual environment and install required packages.

trans-unit.source: Then we'll run the application locally using the default in-memory repository.
trans-unit.target: Then we'll run the application locally using the default in-memory repository.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, select **File**, **New Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, select **File**, **New Project**.

trans-unit.source: The project templates from the PTVS Samples VSIX are available under **Python**, **Samples**.
trans-unit.target: The project templates from the PTVS Samples VSIX are available under **Python**, **Samples**.

trans-unit.source: Select **Polls Flask Web Project** and click OK to create the project.
trans-unit.target: Select **Polls Flask Web Project** and click OK to create the project.

trans-unit.source: New Project Dialog
trans-unit.target: New Project Dialog

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to install external packages.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to install external packages.

trans-unit.source: Select **Install into a virtual environment**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Install into a virtual environment**.

trans-unit.source: External Packages Dialog
trans-unit.target: External Packages Dialog

trans-unit.source: Select **Python 2.7** or **Python 3.4** as the base interpreter.
trans-unit.target: Select **Python 2.7** or **Python 3.4** as the base interpreter.

trans-unit.source: Add Virtual Environment Dialog
trans-unit.target: Add Virtual Environment Dialog

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the application works by pressing `F5`.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the application works by pressing `F5`.

trans-unit.source: By default, the application uses an in-memory repository which doesn't require any configuration.
trans-unit.target: By default, the application uses an in-memory repository which doesn't require any configuration.

trans-unit.source: All data is lost when the web server is stopped.
trans-unit.target: All data is lost when the web server is stopped.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create Sample Polls**, then click on a poll and vote.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create Sample Polls**, then click on a poll and vote.

trans-unit.source: Web Browser
trans-unit.target: Web Browser

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure Storage Account
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure Storage Account

trans-unit.source: To use storage operations, you need an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: To use storage operations, you need an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can create a storage account by following these steps.
trans-unit.target: You can create a storage account by following these steps.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: Click the **New** icon on the bottom left of the portal, then click **Data + Storage** > **Storage**.
trans-unit.target: Click the **New** icon on the bottom left of the portal, then click **Data + Storage** > **Storage**.

trans-unit.source: Give the storage account a unique name and create a new [resource group](../resource-group-overview.md) for it.
trans-unit.target: Give the storage account a unique name and create a new [resource group](../resource-group-overview.md) for it.

trans-unit.source: When the storage account has been created, the **Notifications** button will flash a green **SUCCESS** and the storage account's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.
trans-unit.target: When the storage account has been created, the **Notifications** button will flash a green **SUCCESS** and the storage account's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Settings** part in the storage account's blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Settings** part in the storage account's blade.

trans-unit.source: Take note of the account name and the primary key.
trans-unit.target: Take note of the account name and the primary key.

trans-unit.source: We will need this information to configure your project in the next section.
trans-unit.target: We will need this information to configure your project in the next section.

trans-unit.source: Configure the Project
trans-unit.target: Configure the Project

trans-unit.source: In this section, we'll configure our application to use the storage account we just created.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we'll configure our application to use the storage account we just created.

trans-unit.source: We'll see how to obtain connection settings from the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: We'll see how to obtain connection settings from the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Then we'll run the application locally.
trans-unit.target: Then we'll run the application locally.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click on your project node in Solution Explorer and select **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click on your project node in Solution Explorer and select **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Click on the **Debug** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click on the **Debug** tab.

trans-unit.source: Project Debug Settings
trans-unit.target: Project Debug Settings

trans-unit.source: Set the values of environment variables required by the application in **Debug Server Command**, **Environment**.
trans-unit.target: Set the values of environment variables required by the application in **Debug Server Command**, **Environment**.

trans-unit.source: This will set the environment variables when you **Start Debugging**.
trans-unit.target: This will set the environment variables when you **Start Debugging**.

trans-unit.source: If you want the variables to be set when you **Start Without Debugging**, set the same values under **Run Server Command** as well.
trans-unit.target: If you want the variables to be set when you **Start Without Debugging**, set the same values under **Run Server Command** as well.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can define environment variables using the Windows Control Panel.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can define environment variables using the Windows Control Panel.

trans-unit.source: This is a better option if you want to avoid storing credentials in source code / project file.
trans-unit.target: This is a better option if you want to avoid storing credentials in source code / project file.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will need to restart Visual Studio for the new environment values to be available to the application.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will need to restart Visual Studio for the new environment values to be available to the application.

trans-unit.source: The code that implements the Azure Table Storage repository is in **models/azuretablestorage.py**.
trans-unit.target: The code that implements the Azure Table Storage repository is in **models/azuretablestorage.py**.

trans-unit.source: See the [documentation] for more information on how to use Table Service from Python.
trans-unit.target: See the [documentation] for more information on how to use Table Service from Python.

trans-unit.source: Run the application with `F5`.
trans-unit.target: Run the application with `F5`.

trans-unit.source: Polls that are created with **Create Sample Polls** and the data submitted by voting will be serialized in Azure Table Storage.
trans-unit.target: Polls that are created with **Create Sample Polls** and the data submitted by voting will be serialized in Azure Table Storage.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the **About** page to verify that the application is using the **Azure Table Storage** repository.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the **About** page to verify that the application is using the **Azure Table Storage** repository.

trans-unit.source: Web Browser
trans-unit.target: Web Browser

trans-unit.source: Explore the Azure Table Storage
trans-unit.target: Explore the Azure Table Storage

trans-unit.source: It's easy to view and edit storage tables using Server Explorer in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: It's easy to view and edit storage tables using Server Explorer in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In this section we'll use Server Explorer to view the contents of the polls application tables.
trans-unit.target: In this section we'll use Server Explorer to view the contents of the polls application tables.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This requires Microsoft Azure Tools to be installed, which are available as part of the [Azure SDK for .NET].
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This requires Microsoft Azure Tools to be installed, which are available as part of the [Azure SDK for .NET].

trans-unit.source: Open **Server Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: Open **Server Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: Expand **Azure**, **Storage**, your storage account, then **Tables**.
trans-unit.target: Expand **Azure**, **Storage**, your storage account, then **Tables**.

trans-unit.source: Double-click on the **polls** or **choices** table to view the contents of the table in a document window, as well as add/remove/edit entities.
trans-unit.target: Double-click on the **polls** or **choices** table to view the contents of the table in a document window, as well as add/remove/edit entities.

trans-unit.source: Publish the web app to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Publish the web app to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: The Azure .NET SDK provides an easy way to deploy your web app to Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: The Azure .NET SDK provides an easy way to deploy your web app to Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Click on **Microsoft Azure Web Apps**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **Microsoft Azure Web Apps**.

trans-unit.source: Click on **New** to create a new web app.
trans-unit.target: Click on **New** to create a new web app.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the following fields and click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the following fields and click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: Web App name
trans-unit.target: Web App name

trans-unit.source: App Service plan
trans-unit.target: App Service plan

trans-unit.source: Resource group
trans-unit.target: Resource group

trans-unit.source: Region
trans-unit.target: Region

trans-unit.source: Leave **Database server** set to **No database**
trans-unit.target: Leave **Database server** set to **No database**

trans-unit.source: Accept all other defaults and click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Accept all other defaults and click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Your web browser will open automatically to the published web app.
trans-unit.target: Your web browser will open automatically to the published web app.

trans-unit.source: If you browse to the about page, you'll see that it uses the **In-Memory** repository, not the **Azure Table Storage** repository.
trans-unit.target: If you browse to the about page, you'll see that it uses the **In-Memory** repository, not the **Azure Table Storage** repository.

trans-unit.source: That's because the environment variables are not set on the Web Apps instance in Azure App Service, so it uses the default values specified in **settings.py**.
trans-unit.target: That's because the environment variables are not set on the Web Apps instance in Azure App Service, so it uses the default values specified in **settings.py**.

trans-unit.source: Configure the Web Apps instance
trans-unit.target: Configure the Web Apps instance

trans-unit.source: In this section, we'll configure environment variables for the Web Apps instance.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we'll configure environment variables for the Web Apps instance.

trans-unit.source: In [Azure Portal], open the web app's blade by clicking **Browse** > **Web Apps** > your web app name.
trans-unit.target: In [Azure Portal], open the web app's blade by clicking **Browse** > **Web Apps** > your web app name.

trans-unit.source: In your web app's blade, click **All Settings**, then click **Application Settings**.
trans-unit.target: In your web app's blade, click **All Settings**, then click **Application Settings**.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down to the **app settings** section and set the values for **REPOSITORY\_NAME**, **STORAGE\_NAME** and **STORAGE\_KEY** as described in the section above.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down to the **app settings** section and set the values for **REPOSITORY\_NAME**, **STORAGE\_NAME** and **STORAGE\_KEY** as described in the section above.

trans-unit.source: Click on **SAVE**, then **RESTART** and finally **BROWSE**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **SAVE**, then **RESTART** and finally **BROWSE**.

trans-unit.source: You should see the web app working as expected, using the **Azure Table Storage** repository.
trans-unit.target: You should see the web app working as expected, using the **Azure Table Storage** repository.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: Web Browser
trans-unit.target: Web Browser

trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: [Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714)
